s1: This course provides a broad but thorough introduction to the methods and practice of statistical machine learning.
s2: In this course, you will learn fundamental concepts of data communication and networking in addition to gaining a working knowledge of network scalability, mobility, security, and managing capabilities.

s1: Topics covered will include Bayesian inference and maximum likelihood modeling; regression, classification, density estimation, clustering, principal and independent component analysis; parametric, semi-parametric, and non-parametric models; basis functions, neural networks, kernel methods, and graphical models; deterministic and stochastic optimisation; overfitting, regularisation, and validation.
s2: Apply network design principles, topologies, architectures, and their components.

s1: Describe a number of models for supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement machine learning.
s2: Analyse the role of network standards, protocols, and layered models.

s1: Assess the strength and weakness of each of these models.
s2: Analyse the role of network standards, protocols, and layered models.

s1: Interpret the mathematical equations from Linear Algebra, Statistics, and Probability Theory used in these machine learning models.
s2: Analyse the role of network standards, protocols, and layered models.

s1: Implement efficient machine learning algorithms on a computer.
s2: Create a virtual machine and apply tools for packet analysis and file encryption in a lab environment.

s1: Design test procedures in order to evaluate a model.
s2: Analyse the role of network standards, protocols, and layered models.

s1: Combine several models in order to gain better results.
s2: Create a virtual machine and apply tools for packet analysis and file encryption in a lab environment.

s1: Make choices for a model for new machine learning tasks based on reasoned argument.
s2: Create a virtual machine and apply tools for packet analysis and file encryption in a lab environment.
